description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence in machines.
Machine Learning (ML) is a subset of AI that focuses on getting machines to learn from data.
Deep Learning is a subset of Machine Learning that uses neural networks with multiple layers.
Natural Language Processing (NLP) is a field of AI that focuses on the interaction between computers and humans through natural language.
Computer Vision is a field that deals with how computers can be made to gain high-level understanding from digital images or videos.
Neural Networks are a set of algorithms, modeled after the human brain, that recognize patterns.
Reinforcement Learning is a type of machine learning where an agent learns by interacting with an environment and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or punishments.
Data Science is the field that uses scientific methods, processes, algorithms, and systems to extract knowledge and insights from structured and unstructured data.
Big Data refers to extremely large and complex data sets that cannot be easily managed or processed using traditional methods.
Data Mining is the process of discovering patterns, relationships, and information from large data sets.
Predictive Analytics is the use of data, statistical algorithms, and machine learning techniques to identify the likelihood of future outcomes.
Supervised Learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from labeled data, with the goal of making predictions or classifications on new, unseen data.
Unsupervised Learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns patterns and relationships from unlabeled data, without the need for explicit labels.
Semi-Supervised Learning is a type of machine learning where the algorithm learns from a combination of labeled and unlabeled data.
Transfer Learning is a technique where a pre-trained model is used as a starting point for a new model on a different but related task.
Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) are a class of machine learning models designed to generate new data that resembles a given training data set.
Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) are computing systems inspired by the structure and function of biological neural networks.
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are a type of neural network commonly used for image recognition and processing.
Recurrent Neural Networks (RNNs) are a type of neural network commonly used for sequence data, with the ability to retain information from previous inputs.
Ensemble Learning is a machine learning technique that combines multiple base models to create a more accurate and robust model.
Decision Trees are a supervised machine learning algorithm that uses a tree-like model of decisions and their possible consequences.
Random Forest is an ensemble learning method for classification and regression that combines multiple decision trees.
Gradient Boosting is an ensemble machine learning technique that sequentially adds models to correct the errors made by previous models.
Clustering is an unsupervised machine learning technique that groups similar data points together.
Dimensionality Reduction is the process of reducing the number of random variables considered when analyzing data.
Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) is a type of recurrent neural network architecture that is designed to remember information for longer periods.
Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) is a class of machine learning models designed to generate new data that resembles a given training data set.
Autoencoder is a type of artificial neural network used to learn efficient representations of input data by training the network to compress and then reconstruct it.
Overfitting occurs when a model is overly complex and learns the noise in the training data, resulting in poor performance on new, unseen data.
Underfitting occurs when a model is too simple and fails to capture the underlying patterns in the data, resulting in poor performance.
Bias refers to the error introduced by approximating a real problem with a simplified model.
Variance refers to the amount by which the target function will change if different training data sets are used.
Regularization is a technique used to prevent overfitting by adding a penalty term to the model's loss function.
Hyperparameters are the parameters that are not learned by the model itself, but need to be set manually before training.
Loss Function is used to measure the inconsistency between predicted and target values, acting as a guide for the model to update its parameters.
Activation Function determines the output of a neural network node, based on the weighted sum of its inputs.
Backpropagation is a technique used to train a neural network by iteratively adjusting the weights of the network using gradient descent.
Optimization Algorithms are used to find the optimal set of weights for a neural network, typically through the minimization of a loss function.
Dropout is a regularization technique that randomly selects a percentage of nodes in a neural network to ignore during training.
Batch Normalization is a technique used to standardize the inputs to each layer in a neural network, improving network stability and performance.
Word Embeddings are a representation of words in a high-dimensional vector space, allowing words with similar meanings to have similar representations.
Recommender System is an information filtering system that helps users find items of interest by predicting their preferences.
Chatbot is a computer program designed to simulate conversation with human users, typically using natural language processing techniques.
Speech Recognition is the technology that recognizes spoken language and converts it into text.
Natural Language Generation (NLG) is a subfield of AI that focuses on generating human-like language from structured data.
Knowledge Graph is a graph-based knowledge representation for storing and organizing structured and semi-structured information.
Blockchain is a decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across multiple computers, providing transparency and security.
Edge Computing is a distributed computing paradigm that brings computation and data storage closer to the location where it is needed.
Internet of Things (IoT) refers to the network of physical devices and objects embedded with sensors, software, and connectivity to exchange data.
Artificial Neural Network (ANN) is a computational model inspired by biological neural networks, used in machine learning and cognitive science.
Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is a type of artificial neural network commonly used for image and video recognition, processing, and generation.
Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) is a class of machine learning models that uses a generative and discriminative approach to generate realistic data samples.
